ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I grew a lot in chinese, surprised me how I could go from 0 to nearly conversational in one year of learning a language.

Ao Laoshi was very interested in talking to us about diversity within Chinese and shared many cultural insights throughout the semester. I found this really interesting. She also got us in the habit of "thinking in Chinese" by encouraging us in everyday language drills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are that you get tons of speaking time and there is lots of material for review. You learn quicker than you would have expected, you have to put in the work though. The only weakness is that there are daily writing quizzes which are pretty stressful and take up a lot of review time and I often forget how to write the characters immediately after.
I wish we had the opportunity to do more oral assessments that are online--maybe if not graded but just for practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would totally recommend this course, I fell in love with the language and it may be my favorite class this semester.

Yes, this course is rigorous but rewarding. The faculty of the department are incredible at teaching the material and keeping the class engaging and entertaining so that students can learn the most out of it.
I enjoy learning about language and culture, so this course was very fulfilling for my interests.

Yes, I think that my Chinese improved more this semester than it did in two years of high school. The focus on encouraging students to practice speaking constantly and how safe the environment was were the main things that contributed to this.
